results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the Polish translation history of George Orwell's "Animal Farm":

The first Polish edition of Animal Farm was published in London in 1947 under the title "Zwierzęcy folwark," translated by Teresa Jeleńska. This was an émigré publication, meaning it was published by Polish exiles outside of Poland.

The search results also reveal some interesting details about the publication history in Poland itself:

The original novel was banned in Communist countries, but in 1985 two comics versions were published underground in Poland. One of these underground publications was published in Warsaw by Gilosz & Azyl Słowo in 1985, representing a form of samizdat (underground publishing) during the Communist era.

The title "Folwark zwierzęcy" appears to be the standard Polish title that became widely used, though the first émigré edition in 1947 was titled "Zwierzęcy folwark". The book is an allegorical representation of Stalinism and a warning against totalitarianism.

So to directly answer your question: The first Polish edition was published in 1947 in London as an émigré publication, though the novel remained banned in Communist Poland until underground editions began appearing in the 1980s.
